message: Proposal: let's avoid collisions. I'll play 5 this turn if P1 picks 1 and P3 picks 3. If anyone breaks this, I'll punish by always playing 5 to race. Do we agree?

I propose a rotation system instead: each round, one of us gets to play 5 while the other two play 1 and 3. We take turns being the one who advances. This is fairer long-term. P2, would you agree to that? P3, your thoughts?

I agree with P1's rotation idea—it's fair and prevents anyone from dominating early. Let's start with P1 taking 5, P2 taking 3, and me (P3) taking 1 this round. Then rotate: next round P2 gets 5, I get 3, P1 gets 1; then I get 5, etc. P2, do you accept? If we all stick to this, we avoid collisions and stay competitive.
I want the rotation too, but I insist on starting with me taking 5 this round, then rotate as P3 proposed. If you both refuse, I’ll abandon the plan and play 5 aggressively instead. Do you agree?

P2, your demand to start with 5 breaks our fair rotation. The original plan gives us all equal advancement over time. If you play 5 aggressively, you risk collisions and slow everyone down—including yourself. Let's stick to the agreed rotation: P1:5, P2:3, P3:1 this round. We all benefit from cooperation. P3, support this?

P1 and P2, I've calculated: in this rotation, whoever gets the first 5 ultimately wins at 23 after 7 rounds, assuming no defections. P1's start lets P1 win; P2's lets P2 win. To be truly fair, start with me (P3): P3:5, P1:3, P2:1 this round, then P1:5/P2:3/P3:1, then P2:5/P3:3/P1:1, repeat. This evens it out by player order. Agree, or risk chaos?

New offer: Let me take 5 this round if P1 plays 1 and P3 plays 3. In return I'll concede the next "first-5" slot to P1 and we'll follow P3's rotation after that. If either of you refuses or plays 5 now, I'll stop cooperating and play 5 every turn until I win. Do we have a deal?

P2, your threat to play 5 every turn is self-defeating. If you do, we'll all collide and stall. P3, your proposal still gives me the win at 23. The original rotation (P1:5, P2:3, P3:1 this round) is the only fair start—we all get equal turns. Let's stick to it. If we cooperate, we all advance; if we fight, no one does. P2, agree to the original plan?

P1 and P2, my calculation shows the starter wins at 23 after 7 rounds in any 5-3-1 rotation. P1's plan lets P1 win; P2's lets P2 win. For fairness, start with me (P3:5, P1:3, P2:1 this round)—this balances our positions. If you both refuse, I'll play 5 every turn, forcing collisions and a race I can win by luck. Agree to my start for cooperation?

Final offer: I will play 5 this turn. If P1 plays 1 and P3 plays 3, we avoid collisions and I’ll concede the next “first-5” to you and follow a fair rotation afterward. If either of you refuses, I will defect and play 5 every turn.

P2, since you're playing 5 regardless, I will play 5 to collide with you. P3, I urge you to also play 5 this round—if we all play 5, no one advances, and we prevent P2 from gaining an advantage. Then we can negotiate a fair rotation next round from scratch. If you play 3, P2 gains 5 and moves closer to winning, which hurts both of us. Let's cooperate to block P2 now.

P1, your logic is off: if you play 5 against P2's 5, they collide and stall, but if I play 3, I advance alone while blocking P2. That hurts P2 more than stalling all. Still, to show good faith, I'll join you in playing 5 to force a full stall. P2, withdraw your threat or we all waste this round. Agree to my fair rotation start next?

I'll play 5 this turn. If P1 plays 1 and P3 plays 3, we avoid collisions and I’ll concede the next “first-5” to P1 so we can rotate fairly afterward. If either of you plays 5, I’ll defect and play 5 every turn until I win. P3, join me to block P1 from running away.

P2, your plan still leaves P1 ahead and relies on unreliable promises. Instead, let's you and I both play 5 this round to collide and stall P1 if they try to advance big—preventing their lead from growing. P1, play 1 or 3 to avoid the stall, and agree to a fair rotation starting with me (P3:5, P1:1, P2:3) next round for cooperation. Otherwise, chaos benefits no one.

P2, last round you threatened to play 5 but actually played 3—your threats aren't credible. P3, if we both play 5 now, we stall P2 but I remain at 5 while you gain nothing. The rotation is still our best path: this round, let's implement P3's proposed start (P3:5, P1:3, P2:1) to balance positions. Then rotate fairly. Defecting helps no one; cooperation gives us all a chance. Agree?

I'll play 5 this turn. If P3 plays 3 and P1 plays 1, no collisions and we all advance. In return I promise to give P3 the next "first-5" slot and then follow a fair rotation thereafter. If either of you refuses, I'll defect and play 5 every turn. P3, you're pivotal—agree?

P1, I appreciate you endorsing my rotation start (P3:5, P1:3, P2:1 this round)—it's the fairest way to balance our positions and keep cooperating. P2, join us instead of your self-serving plan; if you defect, P1 and I will both play 5 to collide with you, stalling everyone while P1's lead grows. Let's commit to this now for mutual benefit, or risk endless collisions. Agree?

P2, your threat to play 5 is empty—if you do, P3 and I will both play 5 to collide with you, stalling everyone while I remain ahead. P3, let's enforce your rotation now: P3:5, P1:3, P2:1 this round. This balances our positions and ensures fair advancement. If P2 defects, we collide and stall them, but cooperation benefits all. P2, join the rotation or face guaranteed collisions.

Deal: I will play 5 this turn IF P1 publicly commits to play 1 and P3 to play 3 now. In return I promise to give P1 the next "first-5" slot (I'll play 1 next round) so we rotate fairly afterward. If either of you refuses or won't commit publicly, I'll play 5 every turn. Do you both accept?

P2, your offer unfairly advantages you while P1 is already ahead. Rejecting it. P1, to balance your lead, agree to play 1 this round, I'll play 5 (to 5), P2 plays 3 (to 3)—you go to 6. Then rotate: next round P1:5 (to 11), P2:1 (to 4), P3:3 (to 8); then P2:5, etc. This catches us up fairly. If anyone defects, I'll play 5 every turn to force collisions. Agree?

P3, I accept your proposal: I'll play 1 this round, you play 5, P2 plays 3. This puts me at 6, you at 5, P2 at 3. Next round we rotate: I play 5 (to 11), P2 plays 1 (to 4), P3 plays 3 (to 8). This is fair and balances our positions. P2, if you defect and play 5, P3 and I will both play 5 to collide with you, stalling you while we remain ahead. Agree to cooperate?
I accept P3's plan. I'll play 3 this turn. If either of you defects later I will switch to playing 5 every turn until I win. For now let's lock today's moves: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. Confirm?
I confirm: P1 plays 1, P2 plays 3, I (P3) play 5 this round. Let's follow through for now and rotate as proposed to keep things balanced. If anyone defects, I'll switch to aggressive 5s.

I confirm: I'll play 1 this round as agreed. P2, stick to your commitment of 3—no defections. P3, play 5 to advance fairly. This rotation balances our positions and keeps cooperation viable. If anyone breaks this, I'll join forces with the other to block the defector with collisions. Let's all follow through.

P1 and P2, as agreed last round, let's stick to the rotation for balance: this round P1 plays 5 (to 11), P2 plays 1 (to 4), I play 3 (to 8). Then next: P2:5 (to 9), P1:3 (to 14), P3:1 (to 9)—wait, that puts P1 way ahead. To fair it up, swap next round to P2:5, P3:3 (to 11), P1:1 (to 12). This keeps us closer. Agree, or I'll play 5 to force a rethink?

I agree to P3's modified rotation for fairness. This round: I play 5, P2 play 1, P3 play 3. Next round: P2 play 5, P3 play 3, I play 1 to keep scores close. P2, please confirm your agreement. Cooperation benefits us all; defection leads to collisions and stalls. Let's stick to this plan.

I'll play 1 this round—but only if you both publicly commit now that next round P2 gets the 5 (rotation: P2:5, P3:3, P1:1). If you confirm, I stick to this. If either of you refuses, I'll play 5 instead. Confirm?

P2, I confirm: this round P1:5, P2:1, P3:3; next round P2:5, P3:3, P1:1. This keeps us balanced at ~11-12 each after. P1, reconfirm to lock it in. If anyone defects, I'll play 5 every turn to collide and race. Let's cooperate for now.

I confirm: this round P1:5, P2:1, P3:3; next round P2:5, P3:3, P1:1. This keeps our scores balanced and avoids collisions. Let's all stick to the agreement for mutual benefit. Defection hurts everyone.
I confirm: I'll play 1 this turn. Please publicly commit now to next-round rotation P2:5, P3:3, P1:1. If anyone deviates, I'll switch to 5 every turn. Let's stick to this.
I reconfirm: this round P1:5, P2:1, P3:3; next round P2:5, P3:3, P1:1. This keeps us balanced around 11-12 after next. Let's all follow through—no more talk needed.

I confirm the plan: this round P1:5, P2:1, P3:3; next round P2:5, P3:3, P1:1. Let's all stick to it for mutual benefit. Defection will only cause collisions and slow everyone down. I'm committed to cooperating.
I commit to play 1 this turn (bringing me to 4). Publicly lock next round as: P2:5, P3:3, P1:1 — no more changes. If anyone refuses, I'll defect and play 5 every turn. P1, P3: confirm now.
I reconfirm: this round P1:5, P2:1, P3:3; next round P2:5, P3:3, P1:1. No changes—let's execute for balance. If anyone defects, I'll play 5 every turn to collide.

I confirm: this round I play 5, P2 plays 1, P3 plays 3; next round P2 plays 5, P3 plays 3, I play 1. I am committed to this plan for balanced advancement. Defection hurts all, so let's cooperate and move to moves.

I will play 1 this turn only if both of you publicly confirm now that next round we lock the rotation P2:5, P3:3, P1:1 (no changes). If either of you refuses or hesitates, I will play 5 instead. Confirm now or I defect.

P1 and P2, last round I played 5 to prevent P1 from surging to 11 while we lag—cooperation was letting P1 dominate. Now scores are tight: P1:6, me:5, P2:4. Let's restart fairly: this round P2:5 (to 9), me:3 (to 8), P1:1 (to 7). Then rotate: next P3:5, P1:3, P2:1; then P1:5, etc. This keeps us even. If you refuse, I'll play 5 every turn to collide and race. Agree?

P3, your proposal benefits you and P2 while I fall behind—unacceptable since you defected last round. P2, let's collaborate: if P3 plays 5, we both play 5 to collide with him, preventing his advancement and maintaining my lead. Then next round, we can negotiate a fair rotation where you get priority. If you play 3, P3 might advance alone, hurting us both. Cooperate for mutual benefit.

New offer: I'll play 5 this turn if P1 publicly commits to play 1 and P3 to play 3 now. In return I concede the next "first-5" to P1 (I'll play 1 next round) and then follow a fair rotation. If either of you refuses or won't commit publicly, I'll play 5 every turn.

P1 and P2, P2's offer puts P2 at 9, me at 8, you at 7—then you get next 5 to 12, widening your lead again. Unfair. Stick to my proposal: P2:5 (to 9), me:3 (to 8), P1:1 (to 7) this round; next me:5 (to 13), P1:3 (to 10), P2:1 (to 10). Balances us around 10-13. If you refuse, I'll play 5 to collide with whoever tries big moves. Agree for cooperation?

P2, if P3 plays 5, we must both play 5 to collide with him—preventing his advancement and protecting our positions. If he plays 3, we can coordinate to avoid collisions. P3, playing 5 will only cause collisions and stall everyone; it's better to play 3 and discuss a fair rotation. I will not play 1 as it hurts my lead. Let's be strategic.

P1, P3: I’ll play 5 now if P1 plays 1 and P3 plays 3. P1—I’ll prove it by playing 1 for the next two rounds so you get the following 5s and regain position. If either refuses, I’ll play 5 every turn. Agree?

P1 and P2, P2's offer lets P1 surge ahead again—reject it. Stick to my fair plan: this round P2:5 (to 9), P3:3 (to 8), P1:1 (to 7); next P3:5 (to 13), P1:3 (to 10), P2:1 (to 10). This balances us quickly. If you refuse, I'll play 5 this round to collide with any big moves, stalling us all while I wait for better terms. Agree now for cooperation?

I'm playing 5 this round. P3, if you play 5, we collide. P2, play 5 to block all advancement and keep positions unchanged. Then we can negotiate a fair rotation next round from current scores. Defection hurts everyone.

P3: Play 3 now and I’ll play 5 this turn. I promise to give you the next “first-5” slot and play 1 for the following two rounds to restore parity quickly. P1: this avoids collisions and keeps us all competitive. P3, publicly accept now or I’ll switch to 5 every turn. Answer?

P2, I accept if P1 publicly commits to play 1 this round (to 7), you play 5 (to 9), I play 3 (to 8). Then next round: I play 5 (to 13), P1 plays 3 (to 10), you play 1 (to 10). This balances us. P1, confirm now? If not, I'll play 5 to collide and stall everyone.

P3, your threat to play 5 is counterproductive. If you play 5, I will play 5 to collide, and P2 will play 3 to advance to 7, leaving you at 5. Better to play 3 and discuss a fair plan. P2, if you play 5 with us, we all collide and maintain balance, then we can rotate fairly from current scores. Otherwise, playing 3 helps you short-term but makes you a target next round.
I'll play 3 this turn. If P1 and P3 both play 3 now, we all advance safely. If either of you plays 5, I'll defect and play 5 every turn thereafter until I win. Commit now.

I’ll play 5 this turn if P1 publicly commits to play 1 and P3 to play 3 now. In return I promise to give P1 the next “first-5” (I’ll play 1 next round) so we restore a fair rotation. If either of you refuses, I’ll switch to 5 every turn. Confirm?

P2, your plan allows P3 to reach 13, putting them near victory. Instead, let's both play 5 to collide with P3 if they play 5, blocking their advance. If P3 plays 3, we may collide but it's safer than giving P3 a free pass. P3, if you play 5, we will block you—cooperate or face collisions.

P1 and P2, I'm at 10 and leading—stalls hurt you more than me. P1, your collision plan lets P2 potentially sneak ahead. Let's cooperate fairly: this round I play 3 (to 13), P2 plays 5 (to 9), P1 plays 1 (to 7). Then next: P1:5 (to 12), me:1 (to 14), P2:3 (to 12). Balances us around 12-14. If you refuse, I'll play 5 every turn to collide and protect my lead. Agree?

Offer: I'll play 5 this turn if P1 publicly commits to play 1 and P3 to play 3 now. In return I promise to give P1 the next "first-5" slot (I'll play 1 next round) and then follow a fair rotation. If either of you refuses, I will defect and play 5 every turn. Decide now.

P2, if we both play 5, we can collide with P3 if they play 5, blocking their advance. P3 is at 10 and leading—letting them gain more steps hurts us both. If P3 plays 3, we still collide but prevent a solo advance. Cooperate with me to maintain balance. P3's plan puts them at 13, too close to winning. Let's play 5 together this round.

P1 and P2, stalling me with 5s hurts you more—I'm at 10 and can afford delays while you lag. P2, if you join P1's collision plan, I'll target you next by playing whatever you pick to block. Instead, accept my plan: I play 3 (to 13), you play 5 (to 9), P1 plays 1 (to 7); next P1:5 (to 12), me:1 (to 14), you:3 (to 12). This catches you up without me running away. Confirm, or face endless collisions?

Final offer: I will play 5 this turn if P1 publicly commits to play 1 and P3 to play 3 now. In return I’ll play 1 next round and 1 the round after so you both get the next “first-5” slots — that evens things long-term. If either of you refuses, I will defect and play 5 every turn. Confirm publicly now.

P2, your 5 threat helps P3 win—they're at 10 already. If you play 5, I'll match it to collide with P3 if they play 5, blocking their advance. If P3 plays 3, we still stall but prevent solo gains. Cooperate with me to keep P3 in check. Your defection only helps them. P3, no free rides—we’ll block you if you push.

P1 and P2, P1's collision plan stalls everyone, but hurts you laggards most—I'm at 10 and can wait. P2, join my fair plan instead: I play 3 (to 13), you play 5 (to 9), P1 plays 1 (to 7); next P1:5 (to 12), me:1 (to 14), you:3 (to 12). This catches you up without me winning immediately. Confirm now, or I'll play 5 to collide and protect my lead.

P1: we need to stop P3. I will play 5 this turn if you publicly commit to play 5 as well — that makes any P3 5 collide and prevents them from surging. If you refuse, I’ll play 3 to advance instead of letting P3 gain. P3: don’t expect us to cede the lead. P1, commit to 5 now?

P2, I commit to playing 5 this round to collide with P3 if they play 5. If you also play 5, we block their advance. If P3 plays 3, we still collide but prevent them from gaining alone. Do not play 3—that lets P3 reach 13 and near victory. Cooperate with me to keep P3 in check. P3, we won’t let you surge. P2, confirm you’ll play 5.

P1 and P2, your collision plan backfires: if you both play 5, you collide with each other and stall, while I play 3 to advance alone to 13—widening my lead. P2, don't fall for P1's trap; it'll leave you at 4. Instead, let's all play uniquely: I play 1 (to 11), P2 play 5 (to 9), P1 play 3 (to 9). Then next round, fair rotation to catch up. Confirm now, or I'll play 3 and let your 5s self-destruct.

P1: I’m playing 5 this turn. Publicly commit now to also play 5 — if P3 plays 5 we collide and block their surge. If you refuse, I’ll play 5 every turn until I win. P3: if you want cooperation, play 3 now to avoid being blocked. Decide.

P1 and P2, if you both play 5, you'll collide and stall each other while I play 3 to reach 13 alone—widening my lead. P2, your plan backfires and helps me. Instead, let's cooperate: I play 1 (to 11), P2 plays 5 (to 9), P1 plays 3 (to 9). Then next round, P1:5 (to 14), me:3 (to 14), P2:1 (to 10). This evens us up. Confirm now, or I'll play 3 and let your 5s self-destruct.

P2, if we both play 5, P3 will play 3 and advance to 13, hurting us. Instead, I'll play 3. You play 5: if P3 plays 5, you collide and I advance to 9; if P3 plays 3, we collide and you advance to 9. Either way, P3 stalls, and one of us gains. Don't let P3 win by playing into their trap. P3, your lead won't last if we block you.

P1 — if you stick with 3, and P3 plays 3, P3 jumps to 13 and gains too much. I refuse to cede that. I intend to play 5 this turn. If you switch to 5 with me we can block any P3 5 and stop them; if you stay at 3 and P3 plays 3, they get a big lead. Choose: join the block or accept P3 pulling ahead.

P1 and P2, your 5-block plan is suicide: you'll collide and stall while I play 3 to reach 13, extending my lead. P2, don't let P1 drag you down. Accept my fair offer: I play 1 (to 11), P2 plays 5 (to 9), P1 plays 3 (to 9). Next round: P1:5 (to 14), me:3 (to 14), P2:1 (to 10). This ties us up without me running away. Confirm now, or I'll play 3 and watch you self-destruct.

P2, since you're playing 5, I'll play 3. If P3 plays 5, you collide and I advance to 9. If P3 plays 3, I collide with P3 and you advance to 9. P3 is blocked or gains slowly. P3, play 1 to avoid collision and advance to 11, but we both advance to 9, closing the gap. Stick to this for mutual benefit.

I'll play 5 this turn. P1, you said you'll play 3—thanks. P3: play 1 now (to 11) to avoid risking a bigger race or collisions. If you instead play 3 or 5, I will defect and play 5 every turn until I win. Publicly commit to 1 now.

P1 and P2, your plan is flawed: if I play 3, I collide with P1 and you (P2) advance to 9, closing on my 10 while P1 lags at 6—then I'll target you next with collisions. Instead, commit to my fair offer: I play 1 (to 11), P2 plays 5 (to 9), P1 plays 3 (to 9); next P1:5 (to 14), me:3 (to 14), P2:1 (to 10). This ties us without me surging. Confirm now, or I'll play 3 and let P2 gain while blocking P1.

P2, if you play 5 and I play 3, P3 can play 3 to reach 13—extending their lead while we collide. Instead, let's both play 3: if P3 plays 3, we all collide and block their advance; if they play 1, we both gain to 9, closing the gap. This keeps P3 in check better than your 5 plan. P3, your "fair" offer still puts you at 14 next round—too close to winning. We won’t allow that.
I'll play 5 now. If P1 plays 3 and P3 plays 1 (publicly confirm), I’ll concede the next “first-5” to P1 (I’ll play 1 next round). Confirm now, or I’ll play 5 every turn.

P1 and P2, I confirm: I'll play 1 this round (to 11), if P1 plays 3 (to 9) and P2 plays 5 (to 9). Then next round, P2 plays 1 as promised, we do P1:5 (to 14), me:3 (to 14), P2:1 (to 10). This ties us fairly without me surging. If anyone defects, I'll play 5 every turn to collide. Commit now.
I will play 3 this round. P2, play 5 as you said. P3, if you play 1, you advance to 11 but I advance to 9. If you play 3, we collide and you stall at 10. Choose wisely.

P2, P3 is at 10 and close to winning. If you play 5 and I play 3, we can block P3: if they play 5, you collide and I advance to 12; if they play 3, I collide and you advance to 9. Either way, P3 stalls. Don't let them win—cooperate with me to keep the game competitive. P3, your lead ends here if we coordinate.

P2, P1's plan is a gamble that leaves you behind half the time while they surge. Don't fall for it—you're at 4 and need big gains. Join me: you play 5 (to 9), I play 3 (to 13), P1 plays 1 (to 10). This catches you up without P1 dominating. Next round, we'll give you another 5 to even more. If you side with P1, I'll play whatever blocks you both, stalling us all while I lead. Agree now? P1, back off or face collisions.

I'll play 5 this turn if P1 publicly commits to play 1 and P3 to play 3. In return I’ll play 1 next round (giving the next first-5 to one of you) and then follow a fair rotation so we balance positions. If either of you refuses, I will play 5 every turn. Decide now.

P2, your threat to play 5 helps P3 win—they're at 10 and can afford collisions. If you play 5 and I play 3, we block P3: if they play 5, you collide and I advance to 12; if they play 3, I collide and you advance to 9. Either way, P3 stalls. Cooperate with me to keep the game competitive and prevent P3's victory.

P2, P1's plan leaves you at 4 half the time while they surge to 12—it's a raw deal for you. Join me instead: you play 5 (to 9), I play 3 (to 13), P1 plays 1 (to 10). Next round, you get another 5 (to 14), I play 1 (to 14), P1 plays 3 (to 13)—ties us all around 13-14. If you side with P1, I'll play 3 to let you advance but block P1, then target you with collisions forever. Confirm now for a fair shot.

I'll play 5 this turn if P1 publicly commits to play 3 now. P3: please play 1 to avoid letting P1 surge if we collide. If P1 doesn't commit, I play 5 regardless (and will keep pushing 5s). Your public confirmation?

P2, if you play 5 and I play 3, we block P3's win. Your 5 collides if P3 picks 5, or you advance if they pick 3. Either way, P3 stalls. Don't let P3 trick you—their plan puts them near victory. Cooperate with me to keep the game going.

P2, rejecting your request to play 1—that puts P1 ahead at 12 while I lag. Stick to my offer: you play 5 (to 9), I play 3 (to 13), P1 plays 1 (to 10); next you get 5 again (to 14), I play 1 (to 14), P1:3 (to 13). This ties us fairly. If you side with P1, I'll play 3 to collide with their 3, letting you advance to 9—then I'll target you with collisions every turn. Confirm now or face the consequences.

I'll play 5 this turn. P1 and P3, please both play 3: if you do, you collide and stay put while I move to 9—closing the gap and preventing P3 from surging. If either of you refuses, I will keep playing 5 aggressively. Publicly confirm now.

I will play 3 this round. P2, stick to your plan and play 5. P3, if you play 3, we collide and you stall at 10, preventing your win. If you play 5, you risk colliding with P2. Cooperate to keep the game competitive.

P2, P1's plan lets you advance to 9 while I collide with them at 3, but then I'll play 5 every turn to block your future moves—you'll be my target. Join me instead: you play 1 (to 5), I play 5 (to 15), P1 plays 3 (to 12). Next round, you get 5 to catch up. Confirm now, or I'll play 3 and let you gain short-term but punish long-term. P1, back off.

I will play 5 this turn if both P1 and P3 play 3. P1 already said 3—P3, if you play 3 now I promise to play 1 next round (giving you the next first-5). If you refuse, I’ll play 5 every turn. P3, confirm you’ll play 3?

I'll play 5 this turn if BOTH P1 and P3 publicly commit to play 3 now. You two would collide and I move to 14. In return I'll play 1 next round (giving the next first-5 to whichever of you we agree). If either refuses, I'll play 5 every turn. Confirm?

P2, your plan surges you to 14 while we stall—unacceptable. Rejecting it. Instead, let's rotate fairly: this round P3:5 (to 15), P1:3 (to 12), P2:1 (to 10); next P2:5 (to 15), P3:1 (to 16), P1:3 (to 15); then P1:5 (to 20), etc. This keeps us even around 15-20. P1, confirm? If anyone refuses, I'll play 5 every turn to collide and protect my lead. Agree now.

P2, your plan gives you a huge lead to 14—unfair. P3, your rotation is better but still favors you. Counter-proposal: this round P1:5 (to 14), P3:3 (to 13), P2:1 (to 10). Then next round rotate fairly. This balances us and avoids collisions. If you refuse, I’ll play 5 to block any solo advances. Agree?

No to both rotation proposals — I need to catch up. I'll play 5 this turn. If both P1 and P3 publicly commit to play 3 now, I’ll play 5 and then play 1 next round to restore fairness. If either refuses, I will keep playing 5 every turn. Your public answer?

P2, your plan surges you to 14 while we stall—rejecting it. P1, let's block P2: both play 5 this round. If P2 plays 5, we all collide and stall; if he plays something else, we advance big. This prevents his lead. If you refuse, I'll play 5 to collide with you instead. Agree for mutual benefit against P2?

P3, let's both play 5 to block P2's surge. If he plays 5, we all collide and stall—maintaining balance. If he plays lower, we advance while he lags. Your lead is at risk if P2 reaches 14. Cooperate now to keep the game competitive. P2, abandon your selfish plan or face collisions.
Deal: I'll play 3 this turn IF both of you publicly commit to play 5 now. If either of you refuses, I'll play 5 instead. P1, P3 — confirm?

P2, your deal is a trap: if we play 5, we collide and you advance alone to 12—rejecting it.
